entry.title: Painted with Mesmerizing Precision, Innumerable Dots Cloak Stones in Hypnotic Patterns
entry.summary: Concentric circles in bold gradients, spiraling lines, and bright radial motifs by Australian-Canadian artist Elspeth McLean transform stones into endlessly hypnotic designs. Impeccably arranged on the flat, round objects, the patterns are comprised of countless individual dots in varying sizes and hues. Having veered away from the stippling technique she used in her earlier paintings, McLean refers to her style as â€œdotillism,â€ which is similar to pointillism in the shapes it relies on, although the artist prefers to work with exact colors rather than layer them to produce an illusion of specific tones. More

entry.title: Bewildering Inconveniences Trap Subjects in Uncomfortable Scenarios in Ben Zankâ€™s Surreal Photography
entry.summary: The ordinary collides with the bizarre in Ben Zankâ€™s photography. Set on the street, on construction sites, or in grassy fields, his surreal images capture subjects in unequivocally inconvenient positions: A businessman finds himself trapped under a concrete block, a wood pile stacks atop one figure, and another precariously grasps the edge of a sinkhole. Often hiding their faces behind barriers or through a distinctly avoidant turn of the head, Zank anonymizes his subjects, making their awkward predicaments appear all the more inevitable and bound to happen to unassuming passersby. entry.title: In Roberto de la Torreâ€™s Documentary Photos, Yearly Masking Rituals Celebrate the Change of the Seasons
entry.summary: In regions throughout Europe, ancient religions often welcomed solstices and equinoxes by crafting elaborate garments that evoked different points in the agricultural cycle. Bulky suits of fur and hide might reference the slow movements of winterâ€™s dormancy, while the straw dresses associated with the TafarrÃ³n festival ask for fertility in the coming year. More vibrant iterations with patterns and towering headdresses are known as boteiros, or the centuries-old garments associated with the entroido of the Viana do Bollo region in Spain. More

entry.title: In â€˜Colonial Ruptures,â€™ Artist Sharif Bey Defies the Constraints of Time through Fragmented Figures
entry.summary: Artist Sharif Bey centers his practice around recontextualizing, a process he undertakes by fracturing long-held perspectives through fragments. His figurative sculptures unify disparate materials and broad cultural references across generations and erasâ€”his works are notably undatedâ€”drawing on both the aesthetics of West-Central Africa, particularly the spiritual protectors known as nkisi, and the industrial histories of his family and current city of Syracuse. Largely crafted around bits of his own ceramic vessels, Beyâ€™s works are on view at Torontoâ€™s Gardiner Museum in a solo exhibition titled Colonial Ruptures, which questions the inherent value and power of objects, particularly as theyâ€™re stripped from their original cultures through colonial violence and structural racism. entry.summary: Artists know this story well: an opportunity opens for an exhibition or a festival and in goes the application, but all that comes back is a rejection letter. Animator Anna Samo taps into the unique emotional and mental fatigue endured by creatives who keep hitting roadblocks. In her stop-motion film â€œConversations with a Whale,â€ she turns the prospect of a â€œnoâ€ into a fresh perspective on growth. More
